Discover the nutritional quality of your food with ease. Let us guide you towards healthier choices.
Understand the nutritional content of your favorite foods. Get insights on calories, sugar, and more.
Our advanced machine learning algorithms evaluate and grade the nutritional value of foods, helping you make informed decisions.
Enjoy a seamless user experience with our easy-to-navigate interface. Nutrition analysis has never been this simple.

The American Heart Association (AHA) recommends that children and teens (ages 2–18) consume no more than 25 grams (6 teaspoons) of added sugars per day. For adults, the AHA advises men to limit their intake of added sugars to no more than 36 grams (9 teaspoons) per day and women to no more than 25 grams (6 teaspoons) per day.

The recommended sodium intake varies by age and sex. For children aged 2-13 years, the intake should generally range from 1,200 to 2,300 milligrams (mg) per day. Teens aged 14-18 years should consume no more than 2,300 mg per day. For adults, the American Heart Association (AHA) recommends no more than 2,300 mg of sodium per day, ideally aiming for less than 1,500 mg for most adults.

For children aged 2-3 years, 30-35% of total daily calories should come from fat. For children and teens aged 4-18 years, 25-35% of total daily calories should come from fat. For adults, the Dietary Guidelines for Americans suggest that 20-35% of your daily calories come from fat. Within these limits, saturated fat should be less than 10% of total daily calories, and trans fats should be avoided as much as possible, aiming for zero consumption.
Health Risks : Excessive sugar consumption is linked to obesity, type 2 diabetes, heart disease, and dental problems.
Health Risks : High sodium intake is associated with increased blood pressure, which can lead to heart disease, stroke, and kidney damage.

Health Risks : Excessive intake of unhealthy fats, can lead to obesity and increase the risk of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and certain cancers. It also contributes to fatty liver disease, potentially causing liver inflammation and damage.
